questions.question: What is the role of silver hexafluoroantimonate in the synthesis of cationic phosphinegold(I) complex 1?
questions.answer: Silver hexafluoroantimonate is used to abstract the chloride from the phosphinegold(I) chloride complex, converting it into cationic phosphinegold(I) complex 1.

questions.question: Why were complexes 1 and 4 found to be active in typical gold(I)-catalyzed reactions, unlike complexes 2 and 3?
questions.answer: Complexes 1 and 4 are active in typical gold(I)-catalyzed reactions because they are cationic phosphinegold(I) complexes, which are superior (cid:1)-activation catalysts compared to their Cu(I) and Ag(I) counterparts.

questions.question: True or False: The Cu(I)-bound alkyne in complex 3 exhibits the largest C(1)-C(2)-C(3) angle among the complexes 1, 2, and 3.
What experimental technique was used to confirm the structures of complexes 1-4?
questions.answer: X-ray crystallography was used to confirm the structures of complexes 1-4.

questions.question: How does the bonding model explain the activation of (cid:1)-bonds by cationic gold(I) complexes?
questions.answer: The Dewar–Chatt–Duncanson bonding model explains the activation of (cid:1)-bonds by cationic gold(I) complexes through increased (cid:1)-to-metal (cid:3)-donation to gold and/or decreased metal-to-(cid:1)* back-donation from gold.

questions.question: True or False: The dimeric structure of complexes 1 and 2 was expected based on the preferred linear Au(I)-coordination geometry.
What was the yield of the phosphinegold(I) chloride complex when synthesized from alkynyl phosphine 5?
questions.answer: The yield of the phosphinegold(I) chloride complex synthesized from alkynyl phosphine 5 was 93%.

questions.question: Why were complexes 1-4 difficult to isolate and characterize initially?
questions.answer: Complexes 1-4 were difficult to isolate and characterize initially due to the traditionally challenging nature of isolating Au(I)-(cid:1)-complexes and the kinetically labile nature of alkenes and alkynes.

questions.question: True or False: The Cu(I) complex 3 is dimeric like the Au(I) and Ag(I) complexes 1 and 2.
What computational method was used to analyze the nature of the metal-alkyne bond in complexes 1-3?
questions.answer: DFT calculations and natural bond order analysis were used to analyze the nature of the metal-alkyne bond in complexes 1-3.

questions.question: How does the structure of the Cu(I)-bound alkyne in complex 3 compare to the Au(I)- and Ag(I)-bound alkynes in terms of symmetry and geometry?
questions.answer: The Cu(I)-bound alkyne in complex 3 is highly symmetrical and exhibits pseudo-trigonal planar geometry, unlike the Au(I)- and Ag(I)-bound alkynes in complexes 1 and 2, which are significantly 'slipped' to one side of the (cid:1)-bond.

questions.question: True or False: The isolation of complexes 1-4 was facilitated by covalently linking kinetically labile alkenes and alkynes to triphenylphosphine.
What was the role of silver chloride precipitation in the synthesis of cationic phosphinegold(I) complex 1?
questions.answer: Silver chloride precipitation occurred during the synthesis of cationic phosphinegold(I) complex 1 as a result of chloride abstraction by silver hexafluoroantimonate, indicating the formation of the cationic complex.

questions.question: True or False: The stretching frequency of the Au(I)-bound alkyne in complex 1 is higher than that of the Cu(I)-bound alkyne in complex 3.
What was the yield of cationic phosphinegold(I) complex 1 after chloride abstraction with silver hexafluoroantimonate?
questions.answer: The yield of cationic phosphinegold(I) complex 1 after chloride abstraction with silver hexafluoroantimonate was 98%.
